Simulations

Source: vignettes/simulations.Rmd
simulations.Rmd
library(zazou)
library(ape)

Deterministic situation

tree <- read.tree(text = "(((A,B),C),(D,E));")
tree$tip.label
#> [1] "A" "B" "C" "D" "E"
incidence_mat <- incidence_matrix(tree)
incidence_mat + 0
#>   [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8]
#> A    1    1    1    0    0    0    0    0
#> B    1    1    0    1    0    0    0    0
#> C    1    0    0    0    1    0    0    0
#> D    0    0    0    0    0    1    1    0
#> E    0    0    0    0    0    1    0    1
library(ggtree)
ggtree(tree, ladderize = FALSE) +
  geom_tiplab() +
  geom_label(x = 1.5, y = 1.5, label = "-3", fill = "lightblue") +
  geom_label(x = 2.5, y = 4, label = "-2", fill = "lightblue") 

zscores <- true_shifts <- c(-3, -3, 0, -2, 0)
covar_mat <- diag(nrow = 5, ncol = 5)
optimized <- estimate_shifts(rep(0, 8), zscores = zscores, 
                             incidence_mat = incidence_mat, 
                             covar_mat = covar_mat, lambda = 0)

Solution without penalty is not sparse due to ill-conditioning of the incidence matrix.

optimized
#> $par
#> [1]  0.000000e+00 -2.000008e+00 -1.000004e+00 -1.000004e+00  0.000000e+00
#> [6] -2.386158e-05 -1.999964e+00  0.000000e+00
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 1.030703e-09
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>       17       17 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
round(incidence_mat %*% optimized$par, digits = 4)
#>   [,1]
#> A   -3
#> B   -3
#> C    0
#> D   -2
#> E    0

With a low penalty, the solution is much sparser and closer to the one we have in mind.

optimized <- estimate_shifts(rep(0, 8), zscores = zscores, 
                             incidence_mat = incidence_mat, 
                             covar_mat = covar_mat, lambda = 0.1)
optimized$par
#> [1]  0.000000000 -2.951381468  0.000000000  0.000000000  0.000000000
#> [6] -0.001954651 -1.896800199  0.000000000
round(data.frame(true = true_shifts, observed  = zscores,
                 estimated = incidence_mat %*% optimized$par), 
      digits = 4)
#>   true observed estimated
#> A   -3       -3   -2.9514
#> B   -3       -3   -2.9514
#> C    0        0    0.0000
#> D   -2       -2   -1.8988
#> E    0        0   -0.0020

Complete simulation

tree <- read.tree(text = "(((A:1,B:1):1,C:2):1,(D:1,E:1):2);")
set.seed(20191009)
covar_mat <- covariance_matrix(tree, alpha = 1)
corrplot::corrplot(covar_mat, type = "upper")

true_shifts <- c(-3, -3, 0, -2, 0)
sqrtcovar <- t(chol(covar_mat))
zscores <- true_shifts + sqrtcovar %*% rnorm(5) # simulate

Estimate shifts without penalty

The fit is perfect since all observed \(z\)-scores are negative.

optimized <- estimate_shifts(rep(0, 8), zscores = zscores, 
                             incidence_mat = incidence_mat, 
                             covar_mat = covar_mat, lambda = 0)
optimized$par
#> [1] -1.38367127 -1.27282654 -1.12759012 -0.14523642 -0.11084473 -0.05758979
#> [7] -1.13260125  0.00000000
optimized$value
#> [1] 4.43318e-11
sum(optimized$par != 0) ## sparsity level
#> [1] 7
round(data.frame(true = true_shifts, observed  = zscores,
                 estimated = incidence_mat %*% optimized$par), 
      digits = 4)
#>   true observed estimated
#> A   -3  -3.7841   -3.7841
#> B   -3  -2.8017   -2.8017
#> C    0  -1.4945   -1.4945
#> D   -2  -1.1902   -1.1902
#> E    0  -0.0576   -0.0576

The fit degrades as we increase sparsity.

optimized <- estimate_shifts(rep(0, 8), zscores = zscores, 
                             incidence_mat = incidence_mat, 
                             covar_mat = covar_mat, lambda = 0.1)
optimized$par
#> [1] -1.51130680 -1.25827913 -0.92742927  0.00000000  0.00000000 -0.04123557
#> [7] -1.05167379  0.00000000
optimized$value
#> [1] 0.4967788
sum(optimized$par != 0) ## sparsity level
#> [1] 5
round(data.frame(true = true_shifts, observed  = zscores,
                 estimated = incidence_mat %*% optimized$par), 
      digits = 4)
#>   true observed estimated
#> A   -3  -3.7841   -3.6970
#> B   -3  -2.8017   -2.7696
#> C    0  -1.4945   -1.5113
#> D   -2  -1.1902   -1.0929
#> E    0  -0.0576   -0.0412

The fit does not depend a lot (on this toy example) on the initial solution.

optimized <- estimate_shifts(c(0, -3, 0, 0, 0, 0, -2, 0), zscores = zscores, 
                             incidence_mat = incidence_mat, 
                             covar_mat = covar_mat, lambda = 0.1)
optimized$par
#> [1] -1.497968 -1.300098 -0.891983  0.000000  0.000000 -0.045241 -1.043102
#> [8]  0.000000
optimized$value
#> [1] 0.4971269
sum(optimized$par != 0) ## sparsity level
#> [1] 5
round(data.frame(true = true_shifts, observed  = zscores,
                 estimated = incidence_mat %*% optimized$par), 
      digits = 4)
#>   true observed estimated
#> A   -3  -3.7841   -3.6900
#> B   -3  -2.8017   -2.7981
#> C    0  -1.4945   -1.4980
#> D   -2  -1.1902   -1.0883
#> E    0  -0.0576   -0.0452
